dataset.title: Dendrometer studies for stand volume and height measurements of trees of the western US

address.deliveryPoint: Forest Ecosystems and Society Department in Forestry
Oregon State University
201K Richardson Hall
Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
University of Washington;College of Forest Resources;Box 352100
USDA Forest Service;Pacific Northwest Research Station;3200 SW Jefferson Way
USDA Forest Service;Pacific Northwest Research Station;3200 SW Jefferson Way
Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
USDA Forest Service;Pacific Northwest Research Station;3200 SW Jefferson Way;

dataset.abstract: <section><para>Dendrometry is used to get an accurate estimate of volume and height for individual trees. Volume tables or regressions may be generated. This method accurately accounts for taper by measuring at consecutive points up the bole.</para></section>
dataset.additionalInfo: <section><para>Some of the densities listed in TV009 Entity 8 are based on Harmon, unpublished data based on > 200 samples/species and Forest Products Lab. 1965. Western Wood Density Survey. Report No. 1, USDA . File TV0091.dat (raw dendrometer data) is unusual in that it contains formats 1 through 5 in a single file. This structure is needed for the STXE program (see analytical tools) which converts raw dendrometer data into volume data. </para></section>
dataset.intellectualRights: <para>Data Use Agreement:</para> <para> Any Andrews Experimental Forest data set and accompanying metadata available on these web pages can be downloaded for academic, research, recreational, and other professional purposes. Permission to download data sets is granted to the Data User without a fee subject to the following terms. The Data User will: </para> <para> <listitem> <listitem> notify the designated contact (e.g., Principle Investigator or Data Set Contact) when any derivative work based on or derived from the data and documentation is distributed; </listitem> <listitem> notify users that such derivative work is a modified version and not the original data and documentation distributed by the Andrews LTER; </listitem> <listitem> not redistribute original data and documentation; </listitem> <listitem> acknowledge the support of the Andrews LTER and appropriate NSF Grant numbers in any publications using these data and documentation. (See general acknowledgement below and see web page for specific data citation for each study data set); </para> </listitem> <listitem> send two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the data and documentation to the following address: Andrews Experimental Forest LTER Program, c/o Don Henshaw, Forestry Sciences Lab, 3200 SW Jefferson Way, Corvallis, OR 97331 </listitem> </listitem> <para> By using or copying these data and documentation, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. The Andrews Experimental Forest LTER Site shall have the right to terminate this agreement immediately by written notice upon the Data User's breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. The Data User may be held responsible for any misuse that is caused or encouraged by the Data User's failure to abide by the terms of this agreement. Thank you for your cooperation. We hope your collaboration with our site is a productive one!</para> <para> Disclaimer: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is". The Andrews Experimental Forest LTER shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of data sets.</para> <para>General acknowledgement: Data were provided by the HJ Andrews Experimental Forest research program, funded by the National Science Foundation's Long-Term Ecological Research Program (DEB 08-23380), US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, and Oregon State University. </para>

section.para: An update history is logged and maintained with each new version of every dataset.

changeHistory.changeScope: 4/25/90: Separate study-area files were combined into single files for each entity.
Metadata restructured and moved into SQLServer metadata database LTERMETA. Data moved into SQLServer database FSDBDATA.
Non-critical update to force reharvest of EML for this study database. Addition of ACCESS code to EML and syntax updates
Non-critical update to force reharvest of EML for this study database. Correction for custom unit problem.
Non-critical update to test new EML generating program and prepare EML for congruency checker test

address.deliveryPoint: Andrews Forest LTER Program
US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station
3200 SW Jefferson Way
Forest Ecosystems and Society Department in Forestry
Oregon State University
201K Richardson Hall

section.title: Field Methods - TV009
section.para: <![CDATA[Generally 30 trees per reference stand are measured, trying to set a representative sample of diameter classes.]]>

<para>Generally 30 trees per reference stand are measured, trying to set a representative sample of diameter classes. These values are then entered into a specific program (STX) which calculates tree volume per tree and for the entire stand.</para>

project.title: Long-Term Ecological Research

address.deliveryPoint: Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;330 Richardson Hall
Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
USDA Forest Service Research;Pacific Northwest (PNW) Research Station;3200 SW Jefferson Way

Oregon State University;Department of Geosciences; Wilkinson Hall 104
USDA Forest Service;Pacific NW Research Station;3200 SW Jefferson Way
Department of Sociology;Oregon State University
HJ Andrews Experimental Forest;PO Box 300

project.abstract:
<section><para>The H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest is a living laboratory that provides unparalleled opportunities for the study of forest and stream ecosystems in the central Cascade Range of Oregon. Since 1980, as a part of the National Science Foundation Long Term Ecological Research (NSF-LTER) program, the Andrews Experimental Forest has become a leader in the analysis of forest and stream ecosystem dynamics.</para>
<para>Long-term field experiments and measurement programs have focused on climate dynamics, streamflow, water quality, and vegetation succession. Currently researchers are working to develop concepts and tools needed to predict effects of natural disturbance, land use, and climate change on ecosystem structure, function, and species composition. </para>
<para>The Andrews Experimental Forest is administered cooperatively by the USDA Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Oregon State University and the Willamette National Forest. Funding for the research program comes from the National Science Foundation (NSF), US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Oregon State University, and other sources.</para></section>

attribute.attributeDefinition: Tree species code after Garrison et al., 1972
The total tree height for non-forked trees. for forked trees, it is the tota l length of stem
Total inside bark volume =total wood volume
Bulging tree flag-indicates tree does not taper going up stem

codeDefinition.definition: Tree bulges more than 0.5 in (1.2 cm) going up stem. indicates original reading may be faulty

attribute.attributeDefinition: Multiple top flag - indicates tree has forked top

codeDefinition.definition: Tree had multiple top or is forked

attribute.attributeDefinition: Indicates that dendrometer measure of dbh is dissimilar to tape measurement

codeDefinition.definition: The dendrometer dbh is greater than +/- 5% of the tape measurement

attribute.attributeDefinition: Indicates that stump volume and height cannot be calculated

codeDefinition.definition: Stump volume and height cannot be calculated for this tree

Watershed 2 and Hagan block lter transects (tree data)
Mendel unit snags at the hj andrews experimenatl forest

Greene and Emmingham thinning plots (see study code FS024)
Y = b1*height*dbh*dbh (y = volume in m3, height in m, dbh in m)
Ln-ln transform. y = volume = b0*dbh**b1 (y in m3, dbh in cm)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Tree species code after Garrison et al., 1972
Baskerville's correction factor [cf=e**(mse/2)]. should be multiplied by b0 to get corrected equation.
Green density of component in mg/m3 or g/cm3
